quantityRules.description: Single gecko requires 40 gallons minimum (36Ã—18Ã—18 inches). Cohabitation NOT recommended - causes stress, injuries, and breeding complications. Males are extremely aggressive and will fight to the death if housed together.

temperament: Calm and docile, tolerates handling well once acclimated
setupTips: Three hides MANDATORY: warm hide (90-92Â°F), cool hide (70-77Â°F), humid hide (70-80% humidity)
Primary heating: 75w halogen bulb on dimming thermostat for basking (94-97Â°F surface temp)
Substrate: DIY arid mix (40% topsoil, 40% sand, 20% excavator clay) allows natural digging
Humid hide placement: Warm side or center, filled with damp sphagnum moss
UVB lighting recommended: Zoo Med ReptiSun 5.0 or Arcadia ShadeDweller for normal morphs
notes: 70+ designer morphs available: albino varieties require reduced UVB (0.5-0.7 UVI) to prevent eye damage
One of few gecko species with movable eyelids - can blink and close eyes for sleep (most geckos have fused eyelids)
Store fat reserves in their tail - thick, plump tail indicates healthy gecko, while thin tail signals malnutrition or illness
Can drop tail when grabbed (autotomy) and regrow it - regenerated tail is shorter, stubbier, and lacks original pattern (stored fat still functional)
Originated 50+ million years ago in arid regions - among the oldest gecko lineages, predating most modern reptile families

warnings.message: Never use heat rocks - cause severe burns. Never house two males together - will fight to the death.
Humid hide is MANDATORY, not optional. Prevents stuck sheds which cause toe loss within 48 hours if untreated.
Albino and patternless morphs CAN be burned by excessive UVB. Use 0.5-0.7 UVI (not standard 1.0-2.0).
Basking surface temperature MUST be 94-97Â°F (not ambient). Use halogen bulbs, not heat mats as primary heat source.
Sand substrate myth: Impaction is caused by low temps + dehydration, NOT substrate choice. Naturalistic substrates are safe with proper husbandry.

feedingRequirements: Obligate insectivore - MUST eat live insects (crickets, dubia roaches, mealworms, BSFL)
Best staples: Dubia roaches (1:3 Ca:P ratio) or crickets (1:9 Ca:P ratio)
Insect size rule: No wider than space between gecko's eyes
Gut-loading: Feed insects Repashy Superload + calcium-rich greens 24-48 hours before offering
Supplementation WITH UVB: Plain calcium 2-3x/week, calcium + D3 1x/week, multivitamin 1x/week
Supplementation WITHOUT UVB: Calcium + D3 every feeding (juveniles) or 2-3x/week (adults), multivitamin 1x/week
Alternative: Repashy Calcium Plus LoD (with UVB) or regular Calcium Plus (no UVB) at every other feeding
feedingSchedule: Hatchlings (0-2 months): Daily, 2 insects per 1 inch of gecko length
Juveniles (2-8 months): Daily or every other day, 2 insects per inch OR 15 minutes feeding
Sub-adults (8-12 months): Every 2-3 days, 2 insects per inch or until satiated
Adults (12+ months): Every 3-4 days, 2 insects per inch OR 6-10 insects per feeding
Breeding females (gravid): Every other day, unlimited food, calcium + D3 at EVERY feeding
waterNotes: Provide shallow water dish (3-5 inches diameter) at all times in cool zone
Change water daily to prevent bacterial growth
Leopard geckos lap water directly with tongue (like dogs/cats)
Drinking frequency: Every 2-3 days average (may not be observed due to crepuscular activity)
Dehydration signs: Sunken eyes, wrinkled skin, stuck sheds - requires immediate warm soaks + vet visit
mistingNotes: Do NOT mist enclosure - leopard geckos are semi-arid species (30-40% ambient humidity ideal)
Humid hide substrate misting: Spray bottle into humid hide only (not enclosure air), daily maintenance
Humid hide setup: Plastic container with 1.5-2 inch entry hole, filled with damp (not wet) sphagnum moss
Target humid hide humidity: 70-80% inside hide (measured with small hygrometer)
Placement: Warm side (85-90Â°F) or center of enclosure for easy access
Maintenance: Re-moisten moss daily with spray bottle, full substrate replacement weekly to prevent mold
